title: Polite style and plain style
explanation: Japanese has two styles of speech: polite (ます/です) and plain (dictionary forms, だ, etc.). Polite style is safer and widely used, while plain style is used among close friends, family, and in writing.

examples.polite: あした東京へ行きます。
examples.english: I will go to Tokyo tomorrow.

examples.polite: 富士山に登りたいです。
examples.english: I want to climb Mt. Fuji.

examples.polite: ドイツへ行ったことがありません。
examples.plain: ドイツへ行ったことがない。
examples.english: I have never been to Germany.

title: Proper use of the polite style and plain style
explanation: Polite style can be used anytime, anywhere, and is the safest choice. It is used with strangers, superiors, or those not close to you. Plain style is used with close friends, colleagues, and family. In writing, plain style is common (newspapers, books, diaries), while most letters use polite style.

sections.subtitle: Questions without か
sections.explanation: Plain style questions usually omit か, relying on rising intonation.

sections.subtitle: Noun and な-adjective questions
sections.explanation: だ (plain form of です) is omitted in questions. In affirmative answers, だ may sound rough. Women usually avoid だ.

sections.subtitle: Omission of particles
sections.explanation: In plain style, particles like を, は, が are often omitted when meaning is clear. Particles like で, に, から, まで, と cannot be omitted.

examples.japanese: あした京都[へ]行かない?
examples.english: Won’t you come to Kyoto tomorrow?

examples.japanese: このりんご[は]おいしいね。
examples.english: This apple is tasty, isn’t it?
Is there a pair of scissors there?

sections.subtitle: Dropping い in Vて-formいる
sections.explanation: In plain style, the い of いる is often omitted.

sections.subtitle: けど in plain style
sections.explanation: けど is the plain style equivalent of が (used to connect sentences or soften).

examples.japanese: そのカレーライス[は]おいしい?
examples.english: Is that curry and rice tasty?

examples.japanese: 相撲のチケット[が]あるけどいっしょに行かない?
examples.english: I have tickets for sumo. Won’t you come with me?
